image.altText: A woman blurred in the background with a plant in the foreground

items.synopsis: Chelsea lived in "constant fear" of aggravating her father and says her childhood could have been different had she not been made to live with him. Now, changes in Australian law mean other children will hopefully be spared from the ordeal she endured.

title.children: The presumption of both parents having an equal say over their children in custody battles has been abolished

image.altText: A man and person with a blurred face next to hanging horse carcasses.

items.synopsis: For years, Tasmania's top-ranked greyhound trainer was on the RSPCA's radar, but inspectors could find no wrongdoing despite monthly visits to his facility. In the end, what brought him down was not how he treated his dogs, because he did so inside the law.

title.children: This greyhound trainer has lost his licence — but it wasn't because he broke animal welfare laws

image.altText: Three Indigenous women stand side by side looking into the distance with water behind them.

items.synopsis: As stone artefacts are pulled from waters around Australia, concerns are growing that "tens of thousands" of possible sites of archaeological significance are not being adequately protected. The latest concern is in the Top End, where a gas company is pushing ahead with a pipeline.

title.children: These Tiwi elders believe burial grounds are under threat from a gas pipeline. The company says they don't exist

image.altText: A police officer in uniform guards a door at St Andrews Cathedral School in the Sydney CBD

items.synopsis: A crime scene has also been established at Diamond Bay Reserve in Vaucluse, where the belongings of a man known to the woman were found.

title.children: Prestigious Sydney school closed after staff member found dead in homicide

image.altText: A power pole falls over during a fire

items.synopsis: Authorities have confirmed at least 16 homes have been destroyed in Tara, with dry lightning storms also causing havoc in the region for firefighters overnight.

title.children: Two dead, 16 homes lost in Tara as Queensland bushfire emergency continues

image.altText: A woman in black clothing on her balcony looking at a park, next to a pink stroller with a toy baby in it.

items.synopsis: Lenah arrived at a local park, expecting to meet with a child protection worker she thought would help find her family accommodation, but instead she found police and departmental officials lining the street.

title.children: 'Please, mum, we'll be good': When child protection took Lenah's children, they blamed themselves

image.altText: A group of men carry a body in a bag down a street

items.synopsis: An estimated 756 Palestinians have died in Israeli strikes in the past 24 hours, the Hamas-run Gaza health ministry says. Here are the latest Israel-Gaza updates.

title.children: Palestinian deaths estimated at over 6,000 with UN shelters overflowing, PM announces $15 million in aid for Gaza

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Joe Biden, seated on chairs, shake hands in the Oval Office.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden cautions Prime Minister Anthony Albanese against putting too much trust in China, as war and global instability overshadow talks at the White House.

title.children: Biden warns against fully trusting China as global tensions overshadow Albanese's White House visit

image.altText: A row of men, dressed in combat gear, holding machine guns

items.synopsis: After Hamas launched its deadly assault on Israel, it seemed inevitable that a ground invasion would soon follow. But there are three big reasons why the military is not yet ready to enter the enclave.

title.children: 'You cannot wait indefinitely': Israel has three big reasons why it hasn't invaded Gaza … yet

image.altText: A line drawing of a block of flats with curved surfaces, and a black and white portrait of an older man.

items.synopsis: Esmond Dorney is widely celebrated for his groundbreaking modernist buildings in Tasmania and Melbourne, but about 100 of his designs are missing.

title.children: Hunt for pioneering modernist architect's legacy after records destroyed. Could you be living in one of his homes?

image.altText: Jodie Haydon, Anthony Albanese, Joe Biden and Jill Biden wave from the White House balcony.

items.synopsis: To say Anthony Albanese is walking a diplomatic tightrope as he mends fences with China, while drawing ever closer to the US, is putting it mildly, writes David Speers.

title.children: Just days before his China visit, Albanese is warmly welcomed to Washington — and there's no mistaking Biden's message

image.altText: Michele Bullock fronting a Senate estimates hearing

items.synopsis: RBA governor Michele Bullock says while it is slowing, rental inflation is expected to hit 10 per cent per annum some time in the coming months. Follow the day's financial news on our live blog.

title.children: RBA's Bullock expects rental inflation to hit 10pc per annum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Greens senator Barbara Pocock has asked Bullock about those widely criticised comments from property developer Tim Gurner last month, who told a conference that the unemployment rate should rise to cause "pain in the economy" and "remind people they work for the economy, not the other way around". Off the back of those comments — which, for the record, Gurner has apologised for — Senator Pocock asked Bullock if she agreed with his general idea that increased unemployment was needed to "discipline inflation". Here's how Bullock responded to that: " I don't think those words have ever come out of my mouth, the idea that unemployment has to increase to discipline inflation ," she said. "What has been the case in the last year or so has been that the labour market has been very tight. The [job] vacancy rate at one point was as high as the unemployment rate, which meant there was a vacancy for every unemployed person. "The problem was that the vacancies weren't in the areas that the unemployed people had skills in, so what was happening was that the people that were available to fill the positions were churning, and that was being encouraged by increased wage rises and bonuses and things like that to get people. "That was a sign that the labour market was very tight and there was not a lot that could be done there. Really, it came down to demand. "So what monetary policy is trying to do is ease demand a bit, which will ease demand for workers. "What we're forecasting is that employment will continue to grow, but it just won't grow as quickly as the workforce. So that mechanical outcome of that is that the unemployment rate rises, but I wouldn't put it as you have done that somehow we need to discipline the workers. I wouldn't put it like that." (For what it's worth, Bullock came under fire for telling an event in Newcastle back in June — when she was deputy governor — that the RBA forecasted the unemployment rate to increase to 4.5 per cent by 2024 .)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rise in unemployment rate not about disciplining workers, Bullock says

children.content: Greens senator Barbara Pocock has asked Bullock about those widely criticised comments from property developer Tim Gurner last month, who told a conference that the unemployment rate should rise to cause "pain in the economy" and "remind people they work for the economy, not the other way around".
Off the back of those comments — which, for the record,
Gurner has apologised for
— Senator Pocock asked Bullock if she agreed with his general idea that increased unemployment was needed to "discipline inflation".
Here's how Bullock responded to that:
I don't think those words have ever come out of my mouth, the idea that unemployment has to increase to discipline inflation
," she said.

"What has been the case in the last year or so has been that the labour market has been very tight. The [job] vacancy rate at one point was as high as the unemployment rate, which meant there was a vacancy for every unemployed person.

"The problem was that the vacancies weren't in the areas that the unemployed people had skills in, so what was happening was that the people that were available to fill the positions were churning, and that was being encouraged by increased wage rises and bonuses and things like that to get people.
"That was a sign that the labour market was very tight and there was not a lot that could be done there. Really, it came down to demand.
"So what monetary policy is trying to do is ease demand a bit, which will ease demand for workers.
"What we're forecasting is that
employment will continue to grow, but it just won't grow as quickly as the workforce
. So that mechanical outcome of that is that the unemployment rate rises, but
I wouldn't put it as you have done that somehow we need to discipline the workers. I wouldn't put it like that."
(For what it's worth, Bullock came under fire for telling an event in Newcastle back in June — when she was deputy governor — that the
RBA forecasted the unemployment rate to increase to 4.5 per cent by 2024

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Malcolm Roberts has been questioning Bullock, and started his time asking whether inflation was coming under control, because "guessing so far from your commentary, you're wary, and there are signs that it's not". Bullock replied by saying the RBA still needs time to go back and look at yesterday's inflation data to interpret what it means for their forecasts going forward. "No different comments than we've been making to date, which is that — wary is a good word — we're looking at some of the more persistent parts of inflation and asking ourselves 'Are there signs that those might be coming down in the future?' " she replied. "So yes, we are wary and we don't know if the job has done yet. "We've made that very clear, even though we haven't raised interest rates since our last interest rate rise in June. "We've made it very clear that we might need to go again. We have we had not ruled that out, and we're in the same position."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We don't know if the job is done yet': RBA unsure if it's done enough to tame inflation

children.content: Senator Malcolm Roberts has been questioning Bullock, and started his time asking whether inflation was coming under control, because "guessing so far from your commentary, you're wary, and there are signs that it's not".
Bullock replied by saying the RBA still needs time to go back and look at yesterday's inflation data to interpret what it means for their forecasts going forward.
"No different comments than we've been making to date, which is that — wary is a good word — we're looking at some of the more persistent parts of inflation and asking ourselves
'Are there signs that those might be coming down in the future?'
" she replied.
"So yes, we are wary and
we don't know if the job has done yet.
"We've made that very clear, even though we haven't raised interest rates since our last interest rate rise in June.
"We've made it very clear that we might need to go again. We have we had not ruled that out, and we're in the same position."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you developed a bingo card for the RBA's key phrases in the last 18 months or so, "soft landing" or "narrow path" would be two of your squares. Those phrases were used frequently by former governor Philip Lowe, and they're not going anywhere under Bullock — so it's unsurprising that Senator Bragg asked how we're tracking. Yesterday, Treasury Secretary Steven Kennedy (who is also an RBA board member) told Senate estimates that overall, advanced economies had been more resilient to high inflation and restrictive monetary policy (that is, higher interest rates) and the expected path for the "soft landing" to have widened in many, but not all countries. Bragg: "In the Australian context, is our pathway to a soft landing widening or narrowing, or neutral?" Bullock: "I'd say that ... it's probably the same width as it was. And when we say widening, I wouldn't say wide."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are we going to stick the 'soft landing', or is the pathway widening?

children.content: If you developed a bingo card for the RBA's key phrases in the last 18 months or so, "soft landing" or "narrow path" would be two of your squares.
Those phrases were used frequently by former governor Philip Lowe, and they're not going anywhere under Bullock — so it's unsurprising that Senator Bragg asked how we're tracking.

Yesterday, Treasury Secretary Steven Kennedy (who is also an RBA board member) told Senate estimates that overall, advanced economies had been more resilient to high inflation and restrictive monetary policy (that is, higher interest rates) and the expected path for the "soft landing" to have widened in many, but not all countries.
Bragg: "In the Australian context, is our pathway to a soft landing widening or narrowing, or neutral?"
Bullock: "I'd say that ...
it's probably the same width as it was
. And when we say widening, I wouldn't say wide."

image.altText: Two federal police officers are shown from behind at a Changjiang Currency Exchange outlet.

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police arrest seven people in Melbourne and seize $50 million worth of luxury cars and property as part of a long-running investigation into an alleged money-laundering syndicate it says was operating "in plain sight".

title.children: Money laundering is usually done in the shadows. The AFP alleges this syndicate was operating in plain sight

image.altText: A woman looks at the camera with a look of sadness.

items.synopsis: Nadene Dodd, the mother of Cleveland Dodd — the first teenager to die in WA's youth detention system since records began — speaks for the first time since he took his own life, saying authorities "never helped him".

title.children: 'He loved life more than anything': Mother breaks silence following death of son in custody

image.altText: A photo illustration of Christine Tugwell and child with unliveable home with blue wash and house designs behind

items.synopsis: ASIC has never prosecuted a builder over insolvent trading despite suspicions hundreds of construction companies are taking part in the illegal practice.

title.children: ASIC has been alerted to hundreds of builders suspected of insolvent trading but not one has been prosecuted

image.altText: Man with dark skin and hair leans over water pipe as a stream of clear water flows out over his hands.

items.synopsis: A United Nations report warns the world is "perilously close" to triggering tipping points that could have "irreversible, catastrophic impacts for people and the planet" — but it's not too late to act.

title.children: 'Irreversible, catastrophic impacts': UN warns humanity must act now to survive

image.altText: Two loafs of gluten free sour dough.

items.synopsis: Coeliac disease may be under diagnosed in one in seven kids like Isabel who have a close relative with the inflammatory gut condition. Here's what to look for and when to get tested.

title.children: 'My gran was sick for her whole adult life': Why entire families should be screened for coeliac disease

image.altText: A detective speaks to media

items.synopsis: Cameron Blaine, one of the police officers who rescued Cleo Smith in 2021, resigns from WA Police ahead of a Corruption and Crime Commission report being tabled in parliament.

title.children: High-profile cop who rescued Cleo Smith resigns from force ahead of misconduct allegations in CCC report

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell roars with celebration after scoring a century

items.synopsis: All-rounder Glenn Maxwell produces the fastest 100 in the history of the World Cup, helping to propel Australia to the tournament's biggest-ever victory as Dutch bowler Bas de Leede concedes the most runs by a bowler in ODI history.

title.children: Glenn Maxwell's magnificent hundred helps brutalise the Netherlands at Cricket World Cup

image.altText: a street lined with big green trees

items.synopsis: A Sydney arborist says London plane trees make for a great urban tree, but a warming climate has forced planners to find a more resilient species.

title.children: Thousands of plane trees will be phased out in Sydney. Here's why

image.altText: Ms Mann smiles as she walks down a pier, the ocean in the background.

items.synopsis: A fresh investigation finds there were several failures in communication, staffing and the application of protocols before Monika Mann was discharged from Fiona Stanley Hospital, days after giving birth to twins.

title.children: Monika took her beautiful twins home from hospital. She was dead 12 hours later

image.altText: An aerial view of a lakeside park in the foreground, with a mountain topped by a tower in the background.

items.synopsis: The proposed new human rights laws will be introduced in the ACT Legislative Assembly today.

title.children: Canberra set to become the first place in Australia to legislate the right to a healthy environment

image.altText: Gaza displaced

items.synopsis: Amid shortages of food, water and fuel, Gaza residents worry about what is to come as neighbourhoods are reduced to rubble and dead bodies keep piling up.

title.children: Gaza residents say they are running out of food and clean water, awaiting fate in 'total darkness'

image.altText: United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres speaks to the media

items.synopsis: United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres rejects Israel's accusations that he justified attacks by Hamas on Israel in a statement to the Security Council.

title.children: UN chief 'shocked by misrepresentations' made by Israel over statement condemning civilian deaths

image.altText: Wong, Marles and Albanese stand at lecterns in a courtyard speaking.

items.synopsis: A law firm in Sydney writes a letter of demand to federal ministers, warning the government may have breached the Racial Discrimination Act by "failing to uphold the human rights" of Australians trapped in Gaza.

title.children: Law firm threatens legal action against prime minister, senior ministers, over Gaza remarks

image.altText: woman in a hijab stands in a park looking at camera

items.synopsis: The rate of stillbirths is higher in migrant, refugee, and First Nations communities — up to twice the rate of the general population.

title.children: When Fatima's daughter was stillborn, she longed for support reflecting her culture and faith — so she helped created it

image.altText: A man standing in front of the US flag wearing a blue suit and red tie and glasses looks pensively to his left

items.synopsis: The inexperienced Republican's election ends a turbulent three weeks that left the rudderless chamber unable to respond to the Middle East crisis or carry out any of its basic duties.

title.children: Republican Mike Johnson elected US House speaker, ending leadership vacuum

image.altText: A woman with orange hair and a small black hat holds a small Oxford Dictionary close to her face. Only her eyes are visible.

items.synopsis: Little was known about the 3,000 mysterious contributors to the first edition of the Oxford dictionary. Then a former editor made a fascinating discovery.

title.children: 'Until eight years ago, we never knew who all those people were': How a chance discovery revealed language 'heroes'

image.altText: Two Matildas players celebrate a goal during the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Taking on Iran, the Philippines, and Chinese Taipei in the second round, what have we got to look forward to from the Matildas' Olympic qualifiers?

title.children: The Matildas are back, so what can we expect from their Olympic qualifiers?

image.altText: A black and white class photo with a male teacher. The children's faces are blurred.

items.synopsis: David Ernest Keith MacGregor remained a Victorian Education Department employee for seven years despite being convicted of two counts of indecent assault, an ABC Investigation can reveal.

title.children: Ex-primary teacher kept education department job for seven years after child abuse conviction

image.altText: Britney spears postes holding two awards statues shaped like astronauts

items.synopsis: Britney Spears's memoir The Woman in Me is now out. Here's what she wants you to know about her career, the conservatorship and her relationships.

title.children: 'I am Britney Spears now': The chilling words from the father of Britney Spears and other takeaways

image.altText: A composite image of a man touching some olives on a tree, and an aerial shot of an olive grove.

title.children: How a boy from the outback became an Australian olive oil baron

image.altText: Western Sydney Wanderers' Talia Younis dribbles the football in an A-League Women game.

items.synopsis: Talia Younis was not born when the W-League was founded, but she has just broken Sam Kerr's record as the youngest player in the A-Leagues.

title.children: After breaking Sam Kerr's record, the A-Leagues' youngest-ever player has her eyes on a bright future
